theText: Iancl sob stuff. We can tbink for ourselves. We are here to do good for Australia. We have had 25 years experience of federal arbitration, yet, to-day, tbe financial and economic position of Australia is deplorable. Honourable members opposite talk of the high social standard of the people. Who enjoys it? It is not the tens of thousands of returned men, especially those on the land. We have more unemployment in our midst thanever before in the history of Australia. The men who are workless cannot enjoy our high social standard. There is no clear money in industry now. The man on the land to-day is confronted with heavy production costs but little clear money. The man in business has little clear money to-day. The wage-earners are receiving high wages but they have no clear money. The purchasing power of money is not what it used to be. Our boys and girls who are reaching maturity have little opportunity to launch out on careers. Never before has it been so difficult to obtain employment. We are to-day suffering a severe depression, notwithstanding the past run of good seasons that we have had ancl the enormous sums that we have borrowed. To-day the economic and industrial life of this country has reached its worse stage. During the last fourteen years Australia has borrowed and expended £800,000,000. Fourteen years ago the Commonwealth had no public debt, but the State debts amounted to £320,000,000, borrowed over the whole period of responsible government, ancl the average rate of interest on them was £3 32s. 6d. To-day the aggregate public debt of the Commonwealth and the States is £1,115,000,000, on which interest at an average rate of 5 per cent, is being paid, the annual interest bill being £55,000,000, or an amount greater than the value of our annual wool clip. In 1924 our pension bill was £3,200,000, but to-day it is in the region of £19,000,000. Wool prices are approximately 33 per cent, lower than they were last year; the wheat harvest promises to be poor, and in the district represented by the honourable member for Wimmera( Mr Stewart) the outlook is anything but promising; indeed, there is no certainty of a good harvest in any portion of the agricultural belt in Australia. In these circumstances, the time has arrived for the Government to examine, completely and fearlessly, our financial and economic position. While we are here debating the manner in which industrial disputes should be settled, and the means by which rates of wages and living conditions can be adjusted, we are touching only one phase of the economic conditions of our country. It is necessary that we should engage in a much closer scrutiny, to ascertain the direction in which our general national policy should be amended. We are not in a position to maintain false standards which now exist on borrowed money. I do not care what honourable members opposite may say, I am not afraid to assert that, while seeking to maintain these standards, we send representatives to the Mother Country, where there are 1,250,000 people unemployed. We tell the people there, in effect that they should adopt our standards, and pay the wages which our workers are receiving and at the same time we coolly ask if we can borrow another £50,000,000 to maintain our conditions. This cannot continue. We had a severe rebuff a few days ago in connection with the issue of Treasury bills in London for a period of twelve months, when we could borrow only at £6 3s. per cent. The Commonwealth is reaching the limit of its borrowing capacity, and I am glad that the Government has at last realized that a Commonwealth compulsory arbitration policy is economically unsound. " Our federal arbitration policy has been in operation for 25 years, and has failed -even the workers. The Australian wage earner has a perfect right, in return for honest service, to enjoy sound economic conditions, and to receive a fair margin in the matter of remuneration to enable him to maintain his wife and family in comfort. I do not advocate the reduction of wages as the first necessity in a general economic overhaul. With the good times we all went up together and we must all come down together. In 1914, when this nation undertook heavy war activities, we incurred an enormous war debt. The conditions which prevailed at that time were responsible for the heavy expenditure of loan money. Huge contracts were entered into, almost regardless of the consequences. After the first year or two of the war, we experienced wonderful seasons, with high prices for our primary produce. Extensive borrowing of money caused an inflation of prices, the effect of which is still being felt, and whilst other countries have ' been writing down we have declined to . do so. Like the ostrich, we are seeking to hide our head in the sand, while the rest of our body is still exposed. We cannot carry on our national work on a false basis, and the sooner we face the actual facts, the better it will be for the people. I am glad this measure has been introduced, as it may be the means of improving our economic position. Some honourable members have said that, when the measure becomes operative, there will be six authorities controlling arbitration. authority in each State but one. But these authorities will not be in conflict. The State authorities will have sovereign powers within the State boundaries. It may be necessary to establish a co-ordinating authority in order to ensure fairly uniform anomalies, but that is a matter for the States. I do not think there will be any overlapping. Who can be a more jealous custodian and guardian of the States' rights than the States themselves? Can a central authority be more solicitous for the interests of the people within a State than a State authority? The honourable member for Fremantle ( Mr Curtin) said he wished the Commonwealth and State arbitration systems to prevail. I can only surmise that he knows that the State of which he is one of the representatives is anxious that the control of-its industrial affairs should be in its own hands. Tasmania, which does not possess the resources of the mainland States, was once a happy and contented, if not altogether prosperous, community. For years, Tasmania controlled her own industrial situation in a satisfactory way. It was not until the Commonwealth's Conciliation and Arbitration Act came into operation, that she began to feel thud after thud, and eventually found that she oould not stand up to the burden. This forced the Government of that State to come, cap in hand, to the Commonwealth for a financial Ur. Rodgers. grant of £300,000 or £400,000, in order to maintain her position under the new system. getting back money to which she is entitled. had to carry the burden of developing the State under federal arbitration awards without federal assistance. Western Australia and South Australia have been compelled to approach the central authority in the same way. The conditions experienced by the StatesI have mentioned have, they claim, been imposed upon them by the legislation of the federal authority. A federal industrial authority is too costly, too cumbersome, and too slow, and many workers are tired of the Commonwealth arbitration system. Some honorindustrial able members opposite say that the There will be a separate workers will rise in open revolt when the industrial machinery is in the hands of a State authority, but in Queensland and . New South Wales the industrialists have been taking advantage of the opportunities offered by the State tribunals. I am not opposed .to rivalry and competiconditions and to remove tion. I do not want Australia to be controlled under a system of unification. We have a diversity of ideals, of climate, and of soils, and there should also be diversity of control; with the States legislating in their own interests and working out their own economic life. I do not believe that a National Parliament in Canberra is the best informed body to deal with the industrial life of the whole of Australia. On the contrary, I find that the system, under which we are operating is too cumbersome and too costly, and that we are too far removed from the people of the States. The State authorities can exercise better control and supervision over those things, which are dominating factors in our national life. I do not wish to traverse the arguments which have been adduced by honourable members on both sides of the chamber, but I welcome the opportunity to try out a new system under which, I hope, every industry in Australia will receive a fair deal, and every workman will be able to receive a fair wage, so that they and those dependent upon them will feel that there is a prospect of a bright and prosperous future.

I listened for many hours to the speeches delivered on this important subject, and, unquestionably, some of them were of very high merit. Perhaps the most meandering, as well as the least constructive speech, was that delivered by the right honourable member for North Sydney( Mr Hughes). I was greatly surprised that a gentleman of his experience did not have some assistance to offer the House with which he professed to be in sympathy. Almost every sentence of his speech revealed his vindictive jealousy of the Prime Minister( Mr Bruce). Mr Hughes remarked that, at the recent Premiers' Conference, the Prime Minister referred to the high cost of living in Australia; he continued, " The Prime Minister has been in power for six years, and only now has he found that out." That remark took my mind back to a time a few months after the right honourable member for North Sydney had run his course in the public esteem, and was replaced by the present Prime Minister. It may be well to recall that Mr Hughes was the gentleman who advised the Governor General, the King's representative in this country, to send for Mr Bruce. I cannot forget the occasions when, in this chamber, the ex-Prime Minister has revealed the jealous spirit within him. Honourable members who were in the House in 1923 will remember the introduction by the Bruce-Page Government of a bill to amend the Old-age Pensions Act, by which the weekly payment to pensioners Maritime [EEPEESE: STTATIVES.] Industries BiU. was increased from 15s. to 17s. 6d. per week. Certain anomalies in the then existing act were also to be removed, making the weekly pension equivalent to £1. The then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Charlton, moved that, instead of 17s. 6d. a week, the pension should be £1 a week. That amendment was supported by the right honourable member for North Sydney, notwithstanding that it was a motion of want of confidence in the Government. Had any other honourable member on this side of the House delivered a similar speech and voted as he did, I should not (Saturday). have taken any notice of it, and should probably have forgotten, it long before this, but I could not forget that Mr Hughes had been in office for six years, during which time he could have made the pension £2 a week had he so desired. Yet he was prepared to put out of office a government which did not do something which he himself had failed to do when he had the opportunity. A little later certain ordinances relating to land policy in the Northern Territory were under consideration in the House. Again the Leader of the Opposition objected, and urged that that land should be controlled by an act of Parliament. The Opposition made out a very strong case. The ex-Prime Minister, still f u ll of jealousy, agreed with the Opposition, nowithstanding that the ordinances to which he objected were drafted by a member of his own Cabinet, and that, during his regime, similar matters were governed by ordinances, and none by act of Parliament. He must thoroughly agree with the Prime Minister that some action is necessary to overcome our difficulties. In addressing the recent Premiers' Conference on this subject the Prime Minister saidA critical examination of our present position leads inevitably to the conclusion that the basic cause of all economic troubles of Australia to-day is the high cost of production, and that a reduction of our costs of production is the first step that we must take to bring about a solution of our problems. A nation-wide reduction in our costs of production would effect such a transformation in our industrial and financial position as would enable us not only to absorb our unemployed in useful occupations, but also to pave the way for a progressive increase in our population. Having laid further emphasis on this aspect of the subject the Prime Minister referred to the overlapping of Commonwealth and State arbitration awards. The Attorney-General, in the debate on the same bill, on the 21st May, 1926, after referring to the work of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, remarkedI t is out of all question to consider seriously ariti the uniformity of working conditions the suggestion that this industrial machinery should be scrapped, and all the court's awards, the result of 20 years' work, set aside, interstate disputes being left for the future to the adjudication of some at present non-existent body. I have never favoured extension of federal powers at the expense of the States. I am a federalist, but not a unificationist. . The only way that we can secure a strong national federation in Australia is by retaining the sovereign States each complete in itself, each operating within its own circuit, without transgressing or intruding upon the rights or functions of the other. As a result of -the pressure brought to bear by the Labour party in South Australia, a system of wages boards was eventually established there. I have had experience of them, having sat upon one for some time. When the legislation providing for the establishment of these boards was introduced, the Legislative Council insisted that they should only be appointed to deal with such industries as Parliament agreed they should apply to. This meant agreement by both Houses. It was further stipulated that the provisions should have force only within a radius of ten miles of the city of Adelaide, the only exception being that Gawler was included. theText: I quite understand thatThe honourable member's time has expired. During the 44 hours of debate on this measure the industrial position of the Commonwealth has been considered from every angle. Whilst the case for and against the bill has been stated with a good deal of eloquence and occasionally with vehemence, the debate has been conducted with remarkable good temper, having regard to the circumstances of this sitting. One cannot deal with the matter as he would wish to do without repeating what has been said by other debaters. I have no desire to occupy a great deal of -time at this hour of the morning, but my constitutents will expect from me a statement of my reasons for supporting the measure. The Commonwealth system of conciliation aud arbitration has been in operation for about 25 years and nobody can deny that it has had a fair trial. Because the Government and honourable members supporting it spoke in favour of the amending, arbitration act last year, and are now about to vote for the abolition of the federal arbitration system, it is unfair to charge them with inconsistency. Circumstances have arisen during this year which compel us to realize that this Parliament has no alternative but to repeal the Arbitration Act which has given satisfaction to neither employers nor employees and has been defied openly by one side and to a lesser extent by the other. Those honourable members on the ministerial side who have declared that the Government has no mandate for the introduction of this bill overlook what has happened during the last twelve months and the attitude of the unions and their leaders towards the arbitration court. Prior to the award in the timber workers' case the court had never reduced wages or increased the working hours. When that occurred the prophecies of many, who claimed to understand the attitude of the workers, that as soon as the court refused them what they demanded they would flout its awards, were verified. First, the union went on strike in defiance of the court; next, other unions rallied to the support of the strikers, and then the labour leaders throughout Australia endorsed that attitude of oppostion to and defiance of the court. In fact a general boycott of the court was established. The leaders of unionism in Australia have advised their followers tb defy the court. Many instances of this have been given by other speakers during the debate, but I will confine myself to one. On the 9th February this year 30 of tbe federated unions after the three days' conference at Melbourne unanimously passed the following resolution:. That all unions now before the Federal Arbitration Court bo urged not to proceed with their plaints or to appear before the court officially. Herein we have a deliberate boycott of the court organized by the Australasian Council of Trade Unions with the avowed intention of compelling the judiciary to enforce a 44-hours' week. It was frankly claimed by the union leaders responsible for the resolution that if all the unions agreed to the course a death-blow would be dealt to arbitration. No Government who allowed such a position to continue would be entitled to the respect and confidence of the country. In addition to the open defiance of the court, men who are willing to work under the award of the court were maltreated. The Stateswere either unable or unwilling to protect them. When a law is made specifically to protect certain people, and they defy it, if we are powerless to enforce it we should abolish the law. member suggest that, under this bill, the Commonwealth will be in a position to enforce an award of the proposed committees ? the present arbitration law the Government proposes to set up what are called industrial committees, to deal with maritime industries. According to the Attorney-General, the Commonwealth has full powers with regard to trade and commerce. Some honourable members have asked why other industries cannot be similarly dealt with. The reason advanced by the Attorney-General is that they cannot be dealt with under the trade and commerce powers." Under the trade and commerce powers which the Commonwealth now possesses, it can enforce the awards made by these maritime industrial committees. The Commonwealth then took action which settled that strike in a majority of the ports of the Commonwealth within a fortnight. I have never been satisfied that the present system is a good one. It is cumbersome, slow in operation, and costly, and has promoted strife rather than peace. Some honourable members opposite have said that it costs unions many thousands of pounds to have their cases heard, and they complain that it will cost them many more thousands if they have to approach a State tribunal. Court should not be so costly. We want a simplified procedure. If the system has -become unworkable, ancl we are powerless to institute a better one because of our constitutional limitations, the Commonwealth should vacate this field. Having reached the stage that neither side wants it and both sides defy it, the Government would not deserve the support of any section of the people if it did not take action such as that now proposed. During the course of the debate the hon-' liams) made certain statements with respect to the effect of strikes on Tasmania. I regret that I feel impelled to correct him in certain respects, because Tasmanian members have the reputation of speaking with one voice regarding matters that affect' their State. agree that Tasmania has suffered tremendously as a result of strikes on the mainland, because it is dependent entirely on transport by sea; but I remind my honourable friend that for years we have not had a strike which affected Tasmania to any great extent, because of the firm action taken by this Government against those who were holding up the transport service between the mainland and Tasmania. The honourable member for Franklin that although he intends to vote for the second reading of this measure he will support any amendment to postpone its operation until" the people have an opportunity of being consulted either by referendum or election. It is his right and privilege to vote as he thinks fit,' but I cannot see eye to eye with him. He says that he will do anything to help Tasmania. I represent a Tasmanian constituency and I would go as far as the honourable member in helping to assist that State to progress by improving the transport facilities to the mainland, but I fail to see how Tasmania is to be assisted or strikes prevented by deferring the operation of this legislation for two years. Every strike that has occurred has been in defiance of an Arbitration Court award. I , therefore, cannot understand the argument of the honourable member for Franklin that we The Commonwealth shall assist Tasmania by continuing the present system of arbitration. The honourable member said that the' industries on the mainland benefit to the detriment of industries of Tasmania. He made a statement that I am bound to contradict. He is unfair to Tasmania when he says that there is practically no industry operating to-day in the State because of the operation of awards and the luring of its workers to the mainland. It is not often that I quote figures, but under the circumstances, let me say, that in 1902, there were 420 factories in Tasmania employing 7,466 hands; in 1909, 544 factories, employing 9,322 hands; and in 1927, 767 factories employing 11,694 hands. According to those figures the position of Tasmania in regard to its industrial activities, is not, as the honourable member for Franklin has stated, gradually I becoming worse. As a matter of fact there has been a steady increase iu both the number of factories and employees. During the last two years the position of Tasmania has improved tremendously. Our exports, both primary products and manufactories, have increased. I do not. give the figures showing the progress of our primary and mining industries, for I take it that the honourable member for said that practically every factory of importance had closed down, excluded the mining industry. Cameron) has truly said, there would be plenty of capital available for enterprise in this Work country if those who control it had a reasonable assurance that conditions of employment would remain unaltered. Unfortunately there is no such assurance. There is no guarantee of any security; those wishing to invest capital in industry are always faced with the possibility of operations being suddenly suspended. If they were perfectly Australia is to prosper and our people are to be successful, the investment of capital to enable our industries to be developed should be facilitated. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Theodore) referred to the prevalence of unemployment which he inferred was Not long largely due to the maladministration of the Government. The unemployment has The timber been caused mainly by a succession of strikes which have affected employment in not only the industry particularly concerned, but also those dependent upon it for supplies. It is true that we will As a always have unemployment in varying degrees; that must be expected as our prosperity is governed largely by seasonal and other conditions. A l though production has not been satisfactory during the last year or two, the general conditions are such that the number of unemployed in Australia at present should be considerably less than it is. I admit that some employers adopt an unreasonable attitude which has the effect of disturbing the industrial balance, but the main cause of a good deal of the unemployment which prevails must rest with the representatives of organized labour, who very unwisely direct the men to disregard the award of a tribunal which was brought into existence for their protection. It is idle to repeat that when wages are inflated the cost of living increases in many cases out of proportion to the higher rates. No one is foolish enough to think that industry will produce more than is put into it. What is needed in Australia to-day is that a little more of the sweet spirit of reasonableness should be displayed by all engaged in industry. The employers' interests have to be protected and the rights and privileges of the employees, without whose assistance industry cannot prosper, should be safeguarded. If the employers will provide reasonable working conditions and the employees will give an honest day's work for the money the court awards, production will increase and peace in industry will be assured. It is the selfishness of both the employer and the employee that causes many of the difficulties with which we are confronted to-day. I support the proposal which the Government has somewhat unexpectedly submitted, but which I am sure will meet with the approval of not only its supporters in Parliament, but the people generally. In the ordinary course of events, it will be a little over two years before we drastic step without consulting the elechave to again face the electors, and when that period has elapsed I believe that the conditions in industry in Australia will be such that the action of those who are supporting the Government will be fully justified. sire to associate myself with the protest uttered by the honourable member for Wimmera( Mr Stewart) against the action of the Government in compelling honourable members to work unreasonable hours to discuss a measure of great national importance. The Prime Minister has said that the cost of production must be reduced, but he has not given the slightest indication of how that can be done. Apparently the only way to achieve his objective is to lower wages. Last night the honourable member for Wannon( Mr Rodgers) practically apologized for the present high standard of living in Australia. I am proud that our standard is higher than it is in many other civilized countries, and I shall use every power at my disposal to prevent the workers in this country from being compelled to work under conditions less favorable than those which now prevail. When I spoke on the censure motion dealing with the withdrawal of the prosecution against John Brown, I instanced the strong action that was taken by the late President Boosevelt, of the United States of America, when he satisfactorily settled the great coal strike which occurred in that country in 1902. After a great deal of trouble, President Roosevelt got the parties together. The men were out on strike for higher wages, but he induced both parties to carrying into effect some drastic proposals if they refused. The arbitration commission was formed, and both sides to the dispute were bound to abide by its decision. In the meantime the men went back to work. The artificial creation of disputes has been one of the most disastrous developments of the federal arbitration system. It was characterized by Mr Justice Griffith as " a fraud on the Constitution." The practice of creating industrial disputes by the service of logs of claims, and the refusal of those claims by employers, has been held by the High Court to be legal. Yet no one has ever pretended that it -was within the comtemplation of those in whose minds the Constitution had its birth. The question has been asked why the Government has changed its attitude, and the honourable member for Fawkner wished to know why no indication of the proposed change was given at the time of the last election, or when Parliament was sitting earlier in the year. The suggestion behind his remarks was that the circumstances are exactly the same now as they were in 1926, and as they were at the time when the last election was held, and when this Parliament sat in February and March. That is not so. During last Act was amended, the object being to make a final attempt to operate the system successfully. The Government endeavoured to obviate overlapping, and to make provision for a greater use of the machinery of conciliation. It aimed at giving to the general mass of trade unionists control over, their own organizations, more, unions giving financial support to and ensuring the observance of awards by both sides. The act, as amended, came into operation last year, just prior to the whelming majority of the unionists who federal elections. . The Government hoped that both sides would obey awards and that the system would operate satisfactorily. On the eve of the election, however, trouble occurred on the waterfront. To deal with it, the Government had to make use of the trade and commerce power, and passed the Transport Workers Act. The conditions on the water-front were completely revolutionized. There had been outbreaks of violence in practically every capital city, accompanied by bomb outrages. We then saw to what lengths some persons were prepared to go in defiance of the law. gentleman blaming the trade unionists ? unionists, but I am blaming many honourable members who sit opposite for not having had the courage to denounce what occurred. Later, a strike occurred in the ranks of the timber workers, in defiance of an award of the Arbitration Court, and there were attacks upon voluntary workers who were trying to carry on under the award. Intimidation and violence were resorted to in Sydney and Melbourne. Nefarious practices were indulged in by basher gangs. Having no police force in the various States, the Commonwealth had to rely upon the States to uphold its laws and prevent violence. In Sydney the spectacle was witnessed of a judge of the Arbitration Court being burnt in effigy. that the right honourable gentleman's sense of responsibility would have restrained him from making such an interjection. Further, when we were attempting to enforce a Commonwealth law in which provision was made for giving men engaged in industry an opportunity to determine the issue by means of a secret Parliament the Arbitration ballot, unionists were so intimidated that they could not express their opinions. The ballot-papers were burned, and the Commonwealth Government was powerless to prevent such action. Again, a new atmosphere was created in connection with the timber workers' strike, and we found between 50 and 60, or possibly other unionists who were defying an award of the Arbitration Court. An overwere contributing to strike funds in the form of levies were enjoying the benefits of awards of the Oommonwealth Arbitration Court. Last year the arbitration system was being defied and repudiated by Labour leaders.
